snippet: Showing improvement on memory or reasoning tests, but no longer necessarily in daily functioning, could lead to approvals.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration plans to loosen the rules for approving new treatments for Alzheimer's disease; drugs in clinical trial will qualify for approval if people at very early stages of the disease subtly improve their performance on memory or reasoning tests, even before they develop any obvious impairments; companies will not have to show that the drugs improved daily, real-world functioning.
lead_paragraph: Showing improvement on memory or reasoning tests, but no longer necessarily in daily functioning, could lead to approvals.

headline.seo: F.D.A. to Ease Alzheimer’s Drug Approval Rules
headline.main: F.D.A. Plans Looser Rules on Approving Alzheimer’s Drugs
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Plans to Loosen Rules On Alzheimer’s Drug Approval
